result.markdown:
---
title: "Transformação dos dados"
---


## Alternativa 1 - Transformação

Exemplo: fazer a raiz quadrada de todos os valores para melhorar a normalidade com a função mutate() e adicionando sqrt a count.


::: {.cell hash='Aula7_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-1_c69255b1577a8ef17d70e8ce568fe4ad'}

```{.r .cell-code}
library (ggplot2)

theme_set(theme_bw())

inseticida <- InsectSprays
library(tidyverse)
inseticida |>
  count(spray)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
  spray  n
1     A 12
2     B 12
3     C 12
4     D 12
5     E 12
6     F 12
```
:::
:::

::: {.cell hash='Aula7_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_0c4d84f3d30271a0581710bdf6497ec8'}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(dplyr)
inseticida <- inseticida |>
  mutate(count2 = sqrt(count))

inseticida |>
  ggplot(aes(spray, count2))+
  geom_boxplot()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Aula7_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell hash='Aula7_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_5dd8d78a79400174ad18577615b9e82a'}

```{.r .cell-code}
m2 <- lm(count2 ~spray,
         data = inseticida)
summary(m2)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

Call:
lm(formula = count2 ~ spray, data = inseticida)

Residuals:
     Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
-1.24486 -0.39970 -0.01902  0.42661  1.40089 

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)   3.7607     0.1814  20.733  < 2e-16 ***
sprayB        0.1160     0.2565   0.452    0.653    
sprayC       -2.5158     0.2565  -9.807 1.64e-14 ***
sprayD       -1.5963     0.2565  -6.223 3.80e-08 ***
sprayE       -1.9512     0.2565  -7.606 1.34e-10 ***
sprayF        0.2579     0.2565   1.006    0.318    
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 0.6283 on 66 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.7724,	Adjusted R-squared:  0.7552 
F-statistic:  44.8 on 5 and 66 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
anova(m2)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
Analysis of Variance Table

Response: count2
          Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value    Pr(>F)    
spray      5 88.438 17.6876  44.799 < 2.2e-16 ***
Residuals 66 26.058  0.3948                      
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
library(emmeans)
m2_medias <- emmeans( m2, ~ spray)
plot(m2_medias)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Aula7_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
library(multcomp)
cld(m2_medias)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
 spray emmean    SE df lower.CL upper.CL .group
 C       1.24 0.181 66    0.883     1.61  1    
 E       1.81 0.181 66    1.447     2.17  12   
 D       2.16 0.181 66    1.802     2.53   2

 B       3.88 0.181 66    3.514     4.24    3  
 F       4.02 0.181 66    3.656     4.38    3  

Confidence level used: 0.95 
P value adjustment: tukey method for comparing a family of 6 estimates 
significance level used: alpha = 0.05 
NOTE: If two or more means share the same grouping symbol,
      then we cannot show them to be different.
      But we also did not show them to be the same. 
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
pwpm(m2_medias)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
       A      B      C      D      E      F
A [3.76] 0.9975 <.0001 <.0001 <.0001 0.9145

F -0.258 -0.142 -2.774 -1.854 -2.209 [4.02]

Upper triangle: P values   adjust = "tukey"
Diagonal: [Estimates] (emmean)

```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
pwpp(m2_medias)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Aula7_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-2.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
pairs(m2_medias)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
m2$residuals
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
          1           2           3           4           5           6 
-0.59840073 -1.11492708  0.71145756 -0.01902101 -0.01902101 -0.29657678 
          7           8           9          10          11          12 
-0.59840073  1.03515313  0.36242723  0.71145756 -0.01902101 -0.15512712

-0.56000661  0.24647423  0.70594430 -0.56000661  0.12336860 -0.13497401

 0.24647423  0.24647423  0.48226755  0.70594430 -1.23088009 -0.27108012

-1.24485667 -0.24485667  1.40089464  0.16935689  0.48719414 -0.24485667

-0.41306589 -0.85633950  1.08040235  1.08040235  0.88036232 -0.41306589 
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
hist(m2$residuals)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Aula7_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-3.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
qqnorm(m2$residuals)
qqline(m2$residuals)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Aula7_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-4.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
shapiro.test(m2$residuals)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

	Shapiro-Wilk normality test

data:  m2$residuals
W = 0.98721, p-value = 0.6814
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
bartlett.test(count2 ~spray,
              data = inseticida)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

	Bartlett test of homogeneity of variances

data:  count2 by spray
Bartlett's K-squared = 3.7525, df = 5, p-value = 0.5856
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
library(performance)
check_normality(m2)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
OK: residuals appear as normally distributed (p = 0.681).
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
check_heteroscedasticity(m2)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
OK: Error variance appears to be homoscedastic (p = 0.854).
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
library(DHARMa)
plot(simulateResiduals(m2))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Aula7_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-5.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
#transformação Box-Cox

library(MASS)
b <- boxcox(lm(inseticida$count+0.1 ~1))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Aula7_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-6.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
lambda <- b$x[which.max(b$y)]
lambda <- 0.5

inseticida$count3 <- (inseticida$count ^ lambda - 1)/ lambda
inseticida$count3
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
 [1]  4.3245553  3.2915026  6.9442719  5.4833148  5.4833148  4.9282032
 [7]  4.3245553  7.5916630  6.2462113  6.9442719  5.4833148  5.2111026
[13]  4.6332496  6.2462113  7.1651514  4.6332496  6.0000000  5.4833148
[19]  6.2462113  6.2462113  6.7177979  7.1651514  3.2915026  5.2111026
[25] -2.0000000  0.0000000  3.2915026  0.8284271  1.4641016  0.0000000
[31]  0.8284271  0.0000000  1.4641016 -2.0000000  0.0000000  2.0000000
[37]  1.4641016  2.4721360  4.9282032  2.8989795  2.0000000  1.4641016
[43]  2.4721360  2.4721360  2.4721360  2.4721360  0.8284271  2.0000000
[49]  1.4641016  2.4721360  1.4641016  2.4721360  1.4641016  2.8989795
[55]  0.0000000  0.0000000  1.4641016  0.8284271  2.8989795  2.0000000
[61]  4.6332496  4.0000000  5.7459667  7.3808315  5.7459667  6.0000000
[67]  5.2111026  4.3245553  8.1980390  8.1980390  7.7979590  5.2111026
```
:::
:::


Com os dados transformados o teste de Shapiro-wilk mostra que a distribuição pode ser considerada normal.

Os residuaos ficaram mais próximo ao esperado.

No teste de Barlett o p valor deu 58%, significa que tem-se 58% de chance de encontrar o valor determinado. Como o valor é maior que 0,05 as variâncias são consideradas homogêneas.

teste darma mostra se os tratamentos estão dentro da variância esperada e os agrupamentos estão de acordo com a saída da anova.

De acordo com a anova pelo menos uma média difere das demais.

Utilizando o pacote MASS - lambda valor de x em q y é o valor máximo (lambda 0.5 é igual a raiz quadrada).

## Alternativa 2 teste não paramétrico

Nesta alternativa pode-se trabalhar com a saida original sem transformação. Usa-se a função kruskal() quando são 3 grupos ou mais.


::: {.cell hash='Aula7_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-4_0557840adbf2ebea5a83f5fe447d11d3'}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(agricolae)
kruskal.test(count~spray,
             data = inseticida)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

	Kruskal-Wallis rank sum test

data:  count by spray
Kruskal-Wallis chi-squared = 54.691, df = 5, p-value = 1.511e-10
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
m3 <- kruskal(inseticida$count,
        inseticida$spray,
        group = TRUE)
m3
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
$statistics
     Chisq Df      p.chisq  t.value      MSD
  54.69134  5 1.510845e-10 1.996564 8.462804

$parameters
            test p.ajusted           name.t ntr alpha
  Kruskal-Wallis      none inseticida$spray   6  0.05

$means
  inseticida.count     rank      std  r Min Max   Q25  Q50   Q75
A        14.500000 52.16667 4.719399 12   7  23 11.50 14.0 17.75
B        15.333333 54.83333 4.271115 12   7  21 12.50 16.5 17.50
C         2.083333 11.45833 1.975225 12   0   7  1.00  1.5  3.00
D         4.916667 25.58333 2.503028 12   2  12  3.75  5.0  5.00
E         3.500000 19.33333 1.732051 12   1   6  2.75  3.0  5.00
F        16.666667 55.62500 6.213378 12   9  26 12.50 15.0 22.50

$comparison
NULL

$groups
  inseticida$count groups
F         55.62500      a
B         54.83333      a
A         52.16667      a
D         25.58333      b
E         19.33333     bc
C         11.45833      c

attr(,"class")
[1] "group"
```
:::
:::


Na hipótese nula - Ho: médias iguais, H1: rejeita a hipotese nula que as medias são iguais.

Pelo agrupamento m3, apresenta o resultado do teste de fisher (as letrinhas), cálculo da média dos tratamentose e o ranking de ordenamento do menor para o maior. Pode-se ver nos resultados, 3 grupos - a, b e c. Resultados que batem com o boxplot gerado anteriormente.

pode-se observar que o modelo não-paramétrico apresentou o resultado igual ao paramétrico transformado.

## Alternativa 3 - GLMs

O modelo 4 não assume a distribuição normal. Portanto, usa-se um modelo diferente: modelo linear generalizado.


::: {.cell hash='Aula7_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-5_600fb05ecd3c8f914e5b43959dbf63da'}

```{.r .cell-code}
m4 <- glm(count ~spray,
          family = poisson,
          data = inseticida)
m4
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

Call:  glm(formula = count ~ spray, family = poisson, data = inseticida)

Coefficients:
(Intercept)       sprayB       sprayC       sprayD       sprayE       sprayF  
    2.67415      0.05588     -1.94018     -1.08152     -1.42139      0.13926  

Degrees of Freedom: 71 Total (i.e. Null);  66 Residual
Null Deviance:	    409 
Residual Deviance: 98.33 	AIC: 376.6
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
summary(m4)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

Call:
glm(formula = count ~ spray, family = poisson, data = inseticida)

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)    
(Intercept)  2.67415    0.07581  35.274  < 2e-16 ***
sprayB       0.05588    0.10574   0.528    0.597    
sprayC      -1.94018    0.21389  -9.071  < 2e-16 ***
sprayD      -1.08152    0.15065  -7.179 7.03e-13 ***
sprayE      -1.42139    0.17192  -8.268  < 2e-16 ***
sprayF       0.13926    0.10367   1.343    0.179    
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

(Dispersion parameter for poisson family taken to be 1)

    Null deviance: 409.041  on 71  degrees of freedom
Residual deviance:  98.329  on 66  degrees of freedom
AIC: 376.59

Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 5
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
anova(m4)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
Analysis of Deviance Table

Model: poisson, link: log

Response: count

Terms added sequentially (first to last)

      Df Deviance Resid. Df Resid. Dev
NULL                     71     409.04
spray  5   310.71        66      98.33
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
library(car)
Anova(m4)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
Analysis of Deviance Table (Type II tests)

Response: count
      LR Chisq Df Pr(>Chisq)    
spray   310.71  5  < 2.2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
plot(simulateResiduals(m4))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Aula7_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
m4_medias <- emmeans(m4, ~spray,
                     type = "response")
m4_medias
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
 spray  rate    SE  df asymp.LCL asymp.UCL
 A     14.50 1.099 Inf     12.50     16.82
 B     15.33 1.130 Inf     13.27     17.72
 C      2.08 0.417 Inf      1.41      3.08
 D      4.92 0.640 Inf      3.81      6.35
 E      3.50 0.540 Inf      2.59      4.74
 F     16.67 1.179 Inf     14.51     19.14

Confidence level used: 0.95 
Intervals are back-transformed from the log scale 
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
cld(m4_medias)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
 spray  rate    SE  df asymp.LCL asymp.UCL .group
 C      2.08 0.417 Inf      1.41      3.08  1    
 E      3.50 0.540 Inf      2.59      4.74  12   
 D      4.92 0.640 Inf      3.81      6.35   2   
 A     14.50 1.099 Inf     12.50     16.82    3  
 B     15.33 1.130 Inf     13.27     17.72    3  
 F     16.67 1.179 Inf     14.51     19.14    3  

Confidence level used: 0.95 
Intervals are back-transformed from the log scale 
P value adjustment: tukey method for comparing a family of 6 estimates 
Tests are performed on the log scale 
significance level used: alpha = 0.05 
NOTE: If two or more means share the same grouping symbol,
      then we cannot show them to be different.
      But we also did not show them to be the same. 
```
:::
:::


Isso ajusta um modelo de regressão Poisson onde a variável dependente é count e a variável independente é spray, usando os dados contidos no dataframe inseticida.

A função anova() realiza uma análise de variância do modelo, que é útil para determinar a significância global do modelo de regressão Poisson.

Como resultados, observa-se diferença estatística e as variâncias são homogêneas (diferente do original).

Função emmeans() - calcula o log, response=dados originais (14, 50, 95% das vezes dentro do intervalo).
